'''Baby Tate''' (January 28, 1916 – August 17, 1972)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1970.html |title=The 1970s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] [[guitarist]], who in a sporadic career spanning five decades, worked variously with guitarists [[Blind Boy Fuller]] and [[Pink Anderson]], as well as harmonica player [[Peg Leg Sam]].<ref name="AMG"/> His playing style was influenced by [[Blind Blake]], [[Buddy Moss]], [[Blind Boy Fuller]], [[Josh White]], and [[Willie Walker]], and to some extent [[Lightnin' Hopkins]].<ref name="Herzhaft">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the Blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= The University of Arkansas Press 
| location= Fayetteville
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 62}}</ref>

==Biography==
Born '''Charles Henry Tate''' in [[Elberton, Georgia|Elberton]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]],<ref name="Dead"/> he was raised in [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]], [[South Carolina]]. In his [[adolescence]], Tate started performing locally, after seeing [[Blind Blake]] in Elberton. Tate later formed a [[trio (music)|trio]] with Joe Walker (the brother of Willie Walker) and Roosevelt "Baby" Brooks and, up to 1932, played in the local area. As The Carolina Blackbirds, they appeared on the [[radio station]], [[WFBC-FM|WFBC]], broadcasting from The Jack Tar Hotel,<ref name="Bastin">{{cite book
| first= Bruce
| last= Bastin
| year= 1995
| title= Red River Blues
| edition= 
| publisher= University of Illinois Press 
| location= Illinois
| isbn= 0-252-01213-5
| page= 177}}</ref> but for the rest of the 1930s worked for a living, mainly as a mason.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p143544/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Baby Tate |author=Erlewine, Stephen Thomas |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 12, 2010}}</ref>

Baby Tate served in the [[United States Army]] infantry during [[World War II]] in the south of England, and did not return to the Spartanburg/Greenville [[nightclub|club]] circuit until 1946. Nevertheless, in 1950 Tate claimed to have [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] several (unreleased) tracks for the [[Kapp Records|Kapp]] [[record label|label]]. Relocating to [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]], he performed solo before forming an occasional [[duet|duo]] with [[Pink Anderson]]; a working relationship that endured through to the 1970s when Anderson suffered from stroke.<ref name="AMG"/>

Tate released his only [[album]], ''Blues of Baby Tate: See What You Done Done'', in 1962, and twelve months later appeared in Sam Charters' [[documentary film]] ''The Blues''. Throughout the 1960s Tate performed irregularly across the [[United States|US]].<ref name="AMG"/> Utilising harmonica player, [[Peg Leg Sam]], or guitarists Baby Brooks or McKinley Ellis, Tate recorded nearly sixty tracks in  1970 and 1971 for [[Peter B. Lowry]], but the proposed album remained unreleased once Tate unexpectedly died in the summer of 1972.<ref name="Wirz"/> He appeared at a concert at the [[State University of New York at New Paltz]], [[New York]] as a result of Lowry's efforts in the Spring of 1972.

Tate died from the effects of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], in the [[Veterans Health Administration|VA Hospital]] in [[Columbia, South Carolina]], in August 1972, at the age of 56.<ref name="AMG"/>

In January 2011, Baby Tate was nominated for The 10th Annual [[Independent Music Awards]] in the Blues Song category for "See What You Done Done".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/artist/baby-tate-classic-appalachian-blues |title=Baby Tate (Classic Appalachian Blues) |publisher=Independentmusicawards.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-30}}</ref>

[[Folkways Records|Smithsonian Folkways]] released a [[compilation album]] on February 16, 2010, titled ''Classic Appalachian Blues''.  It featured the Baby Tate number, "See What You Done Done."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.shorefire.com/index.php?a=pressrelease&o=3581 |title=Shore Fire Media - Boutique Public Relations Firm |publisher=Shorefire.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
